_header: This mighty William Duke of Normandy
Note: Some MSS have further stanzas added, but not by Lydgate; for variant text with prefixed additional kings, see 1472 and for couplet-version sometimes incorporating lines from this one, see 727.
Title(s): Verses on the Kings of England (Lydgate)
Bibliographic Ghosts: Oxford, Bodleian Library Digby 196 (SC 1797), ff. 65- : see 3158; London, British Library Lansdowne 210, ff. 14v-42v: moved to 1472; Oxford, Bodleian Library Douce g.2 (SC 22005), a roll: moved to 727; Sotheby Sale, 24 June 1980, lot 42 (New Haven, Yale University, Beinecke Library, Takamiya Deposit 52): moved to 727; Oxford, Bodleian Library, Ashmole 456 (printed book)
_description: John Lydgate, Verses on the Kings of England (to Henry VI) — generally fifteen stanzas rhyme royal, but there are many variants

BodAsh59.First Lines:
Tus mighty William Duke of NormandieAs bookis olde maken
                    mencyon…
BodAsh59.Last Lines:
…Of vertuous lyff chosyn him for his knightLonge to reioysshe
                    and regne here in his right
BodAsh59.Attributed Title:
Nowe here folowen þe names of þe Kinges of England frome þe
                    conquest of Duc William of Normandye (f. 75)

Bod48.First Lines:
This myghtie Willeame duke off normandyeAs bookes olde make
                    mencioun…
Bod48.Last Lines:
…To whom god hath giffen sufficiaunceOff vertuose lyfe &
                    chose hym for his knyghte &c
Bod48.Note:
Ends imperfectly after line 104, with ‘et
                    cetera’

Bod131.First Lines:
þis myghty william duke of Northmandyþat by iuste tytill
                    And also by Chyualery
Bod131.Last Lines:
…Now lord send hym siche gouernaunceLong to reioyse &
                    reigne in his ryght

Bod686.First Lines:
This mighti William duke of normandieAs bokes olde maketh
                    mencioun…
Bod686.Last Lines:
…Now lord send hym siche gouernaunceLong to reioyse &
                    reigne in his ryght
Bod686.Attributed Author: …be Dan Iohn Lydgate Monke of Bury (f. 184v)
Bod686.Attributed Title:
Here begynneþ a lytel Tretis made and compyled in Balade be Dan Iohn
                    Lydgate Monke of Bury of al the kynges þat hath regned sethen Wyllian
                    Conquerour (f. 184v); Here endeth the tretis of alle the kynges
                    whiche hath regned in this lande sethen þe tyme of William the Conquerour
                    (f. 186)

Bod912.First Lines:
This myȝghty Willeam Duke of NormandieAs bokis olde makyth
                    mencioun…
Bod912.Last Lines:
…A vertuous lif & chose hym for his knyghtLong to reioyse
                    & regne here yn his myght

BodDig186.First Lines:
This myghty duke of NormondyAs bokes ald makes
                    mencion…
BodDig186.Last Lines:
…xxxv yere he was here kyngelyth att Westmynster This trewth
                    and no lesynge

BodFair16.First Lines:
The myghty William duke of NormandyeAs bokes olde maken
                    mencyoun…
BodFair16.Last Lines:
…Of vertuouse lyf & chose hym for his knyghtLonge to
                    reioyce & regne here in his right
BodFair16.Note:
Added to MS by a contemporary hand; after last line, concludes,
                    ‘Summa annorum a tempore Willelmi ducis normanorum vsque ad tempus henrici
                    sexti CCC xxvti’ (f. 332v)
BodFair16.Attributed Title:
The regnynge of kynges After the conquest by the Monke of Bury (f.
                        330v)
BodFair16.Facsimiles:
Norton-Smith,  John. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Bodleian Library MS Fairfax 16.
         London: Scolar Press, 1979.

BodRawC48.First Lines:
[t]His myhti William Duke of Norma[ ]As bookis old make
                    mencion…
BodRawC48.Last Lines:
…Off vertuous liff and chose hym for his knyhtLong to
                    reioisshe and regne heer in his riht

The regnynge of kynges After the conquest by the Monke of Bury (f.

This myghti Wyllyam duke of normandyAs bukis old make

CamGon249.First Lines:
Thys myghty William Duke off NormandyeAs bokes olde makys
                    mencioun…
CamGon249.Last Lines:
…Regned x ȝere qwo so List have rewardLyth att
                    Westmenstre not ferre from seynt Edward…
CamGon249.Note: Incomplete: first 98 lines, ending with stanza on Henry V; scribe John Herryson
CamGon249.Attributed Title:
How long euery Kyng reygned fro Willyam Conquerer vnto kyng henry the
                        vth inclusiue (f. 127)

CamJes56.First Lines:
[t]his myghty William duke of NormandyeAs bookes olde makith
                    mencion…
CamJes56.Last Lines:
…Of vertuos lyif and chose hym for his knyghtLonge to reioyssh
                    and Regne here in his right
CamJes56.Note:
Seventeenth-century transcription is Oxford,  Bodleian Library Tanner 383 (SC 10210), ff.
                    51-54
CamJes56.Attributed Title:
Incipit tractatus de regibus Anglie post conquestum (f.
                    46)

CamTCC601.First Lines:
tHYS myghty Wyllyam Duke of NormandyAs bokes olde make
                    mencion…
CamTCC601.Last Lines:
…Reygnyd with moche trobyll full xxxix yereAnd buryed at
                    Chartsey yef ye lyst to here
CamTCC601.Note: With additional heading but no stanza for Edward IV

BLAdd31042.First Lines: This myghty Willyam Duke of NormandyAls bokes olde maken mensione…
BLAdd31042.Last Lines: …Wan Scotlande maugre þe Scottis strangeAnd alle Wales in despite of alle þaire myghte…
BLAdd31042.Note:
Incomplete: first 63 lines, ending with Edward I; includes names of
                    kings at head of each stanza, e.g., “Willelmus conquestor Dux
                    Normannorum” (f. 96).

BLAdd34360.First Lines:
[T]His myghti William Duk of normandyAs bokes old makith
                    mencioun…
BLAdd34360.Last Lines:
…Goode lyf and longe I pray to god hym sendAnd that seynt
                    George be with hym in his right
BLAdd34360.Note:
113 lines, with added eight-line stanza to Edward IV; names of kings at
                    head of each stanza, e.g., ‘Willelmus conquestor’

BlCottGalEVIII.First Lines:
Thys myghti [ ]ll[ ] NormandyAs bokes [ ]cyounBe iust tityl [
                    ]ryeMade kynge [ ] albyoun…
BlCottGalEVIII.Last Lines:
…[ ] lyef & Chose hym for hys knyght[ ] reyeyse & to
                    regne here in hys ryght
BlCottGalEVIII.Note: Written as prose; one side of page lost, causing gaps

BLCottTitDXX.First Lines:
This mighti William Duc off normandyAs bokys old maken
                    mension…
BLCottTitDXX.Last Lines:
…Afftyr to Westmynster hys body cared washerry the iiij-the
                    next crowned in certeyn…
BLCottTitDXX.Note:
Incomplete: first 85 lines, ending after first line on Henry IV; with
                    king’s names at head of each stanza, e.g. ‘Willelmus
                    conquerrour’.

BLEge1995.First Lines:
This myghty William Duke of NormandyeAs bokys olde make
                    mencyon…
BLEge1995.Last Lines:
…A vertusse lyffe and chosyn for hys knyghtlong he hathe
                    reioysyd bothe by day and nyght
BLEge1995.Note:
Names of kings at head of each stanza, e.g. ‘Willelmus
                    conquestor’
BLEge1995.Attributed Title:
CROnycles of alle kynges of Englonde aftyr the Conqueste as of hyr namys
                    ande where that they bene I byryde (f. 110)
BLEge1995.Editions:
Gairdner,  James,
                        ed.  
             Historical Collections of a Citizen of London.
Camden Society
         n.s. 17 (1876): 49-54.

BLHar2169.First Lines:
Thys Wylyam dewke of normandyeAs bokys olde makyth
                    mencyun…
BLHar2169.Last Lines:
…of wertue lyfe and chose hym for hys knyghtlonge to regoyse
                    and reygne yn hys reyght
BLHar2169.Note:
Portraits of William Conqueror, Henry V and VI, each accompanied by a
                    single stanza written as prose
BLHar2169.Editions:
“A Fifteenth-Century Book of Arms.” 
             The Ancestor
         no. 3 (October, 1902): 185-213: 186-8.

BLHar2251.First Lines:
This myghti William Duk of NormandyeAs bokes old makith
                    mencioun…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…Of vertuous lyf and chose hym for his knyghtLong to Reioyse
                    and Reigne in his rightComforth al thirsty and drynke with
                    gladnesReioyse with myrth though ye have nat to spendThe tyme is come
                    to avoyden yowre distresEdward the fourth theold wronges toamendIs
                    wele disposed in wille and to defendHis lond and people in dede with kynne
                    and myghtGoode lyf and longe I pray to god hym sendAnd that seynt
                    George be with hym in his right

BLHar2261.First Lines:
This myȝhty William duke of normandyeAs bookes olde makethe
                    mencion…
BLHar2261.Last Lines:
…With vertuous life and chose hym to his knyȝhteLonge to
                    reioyce & reigne here in his ryȝhte

BLHar7333.First Lines:
This myghty William duke of NormandyAs bokes olde maken
                    mencyoun…
BLHar7333.Last Lines:

                    and regne here in myght

BLLan699.First Lines:
This myhti William duke of NormandieAs bookis old make
                    mencioun…
BLLan699.Last Lines:

BLLan699.Attributed Title:
Incipit quedam compilatio de Regibus Angliae (f.

BLLan762.First Lines:
This myghtie William duke of NormandyAs bokys olde maketh
                    mencioun…
BLLan762.Last Lines:
…And reyned xxiij yere as I tell canEntired at Westmynstre
                    lyke A noble man
BLLan762.Note: With added stanzas to Henry VII
BLLan762.Attributed Title: Willelmus Conquestor Et Normani Regi A conquestum (f. 10)

BLRoy18Dii.First Lines: The fyrst William myghty duke of Normandy.As aunciente Croniculis makithe mencyon.By Iust titill and conquest gat the monarchy.Of englande sum tyme called brutes Albyon…
BLRoy18Dii.Last Lines: …God graunte to hym grace of his mercyfull benygnyte.Longe to InIoye his septure withe honoure and felicite.
BLRoy18Dii.Note: Perhaps best characterized as a redaction of Lydgate’s “Kings of England” but with variant text in virtually every line and added stanzas carrying the history down to the reign of Henry VIII.
BLRoy18Dii.Attributed Title: IN this litill tretis men may se And be Indusyde To the reyngne of the kingis of Inglande & ther namys withall. ffrom William conqueror to this day yf they take hede Of ther vertuous & of ther vicis it makithe a breue rehersall. Of them whiche shall folow for A memoriall. And also it dothe tell wher euery kinge dothe ly. ffrom kinge William conquerour vii to the viij kinge henry. (f. 181); THe reignes of the kyngis of Englande (f. 183, in rubric)
BLRoy18Dii.Facsimiles:
Digital Facsimile of British Library MS Royal 18 D II.
         2015; http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Royal_MS_18_D_II.

BLSto69.First Lines:
Thys myghty Wyllyam duke of NormondyeAs bokes olde makyth
                    messyoun…
BLSto69.Last Lines:
…The space reygnyd fully of ix yereHis hert buryed yn Roon att
                    the hye autyr…
BLSto69.Note: Incomplete: First 42 lines, ending with Richard I

IpswichSRO.First Lines:
This mighty William of NormandyAs Bokys olde makith
                    mencioun…
IpswichSRO.Last Lines:
…Of vertuos lyffe & chose hym for his knyghtAt Wyndesore
                    buried And myracles doth by goddys myght

“Rhyming Chronicle of the Kings of England (William I to Edward IV From

         n.s. 1 (1885): 38-41: 38-41.
White,  C. H. Evelyn. 
             The Great Domesday Book of Ipswich, Liber Sextus.
         Ipswich: Pawsey & Hayes, 1885: 31-34.

Lam306.First Lines:
THis myghti William Duke off Normandieas bokes olde maketh
                    mencion…
Lam306.Last Lines:
…put downe from the Crowne by all the ComynsSo he Regned kynge
                    here all moste xxxix yere
Lam306.Note: Written as prose; last stanza re-written, becomes prose
Lam306.Editions:
Gairdner,  James,
                        ed.  
             Three Fifteenth-Century Chronicles.
Camden Society
         n.s. 28 (1880): 28-31.
